The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about trees, how to communicate scientifically, and the way that nature interacts with culture.
I learned a lot about the physiological processes of trees as well as how trees fit into their broader ecosystems and the world.

In one semester, we learned so much about trees. We started with what it means to be a tree. From there we moved into the history and evolution of trees and the environment. By the middle of the semester, we were all well versed in the structural properties and biological processes of trees which maintained a strong portion of about half the course. In the last third of the class, we learned about furniture, instruments, invasive species, carbon exchange, forest stages, limitations to tree growth, and climate change. As an Environmental Studies major, this course was a great way to explore trees in the context of climate change and the importance of trees in our ecosystem.
I learned about tree anatomy and physiology. I also learned about their participation ecosystems as a whole and life cycle uses of wood.
This course was an introduction to environmental biology through the lens of tree physiology.
I learned a lot about tree anatomy.
I learned about the biology of trees.
A complete look at a tree's biology and how a tree reacts to external conditions. Learned a little bit about forests and wood use in instruments and furniture.

I gained a vast amount of knowledge about the inner workings of trees and other plants. I gained a good foundation of knowledge about how plants work and learned how valuable they are to our environment. I also learned about human impacts on plant life and I gained a new lens to look at nature through. I now have a greater appreciation for the trees, plants, and animals I see everyday.
The biotic and abiotic functions of a tree as well as environmental conditions that trees live in.
How plants work, their role in the environment, uses and human interactions with trees, the anatomy of trees
I feel I have an incredible foundation to my understanding of the ecological importance and functionality of trees and other flora.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is all around great!

I really loved most of this class. I found most of the lectures to be very interesting and I thought the assignments and tests contributed to my learning and overall understanding in a way few classes do. The tests were also very straightforward and although semi challenging, they always felt like a fair test of my knowledge and growth in the class. I would have really loved maybe slightly less furniture/music info and more tree identification and practical identification knowledge.
This was an excellent course and there really is nothing to improve.
I don't think there were any weaknesses in this course. It was awesome.
The course is very organized. The instructors are very passionate.
A strength of this course was the assignments that made us walk outside and appreciate the trees around Yale's campus.

strengths: lectures are interesting and the professor is very engaging. The assignments are very manageable and even fun at times. The exams capture what we have learned without being extremely difficult. 
weaknesses: none

The lectures could be kind of try, as it was often hard to follow along with what was actually important for us to take away. It was difficult to study for tests given the lack of clarity about what would be on them and where we could find the material. Also, I was hoping I would learn more about tree identification from this course. 

BUT I really enjoyed everything else about the class! The assignments were all super engaging- the kinds of assignments that require you to walk around, explore campus, take pictures, and look at plant cells through a paper microscope. All of the discussions were also wonderful. People in this class came from all different backgrounds and majors (but all liked trees), so there were always quite a few different perspectives to draw on in discussion. 

Overall, the lectures could definitely use more clarity, but everything else about the course was fantastic.

Strengths: Engaging, fast paced but well understood, amazing teacher, niche topic
Weaknesses: Cant think of any
I do not feel like I learned a particularly great amount, but the course has a low workload and the PSETs were often fun and engaging, which I really enjoyed.
Interesting and useful information. I wish lectures were a little clearer in terms of information related to the tests.
The course was done incredibly well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All practices were good.

I really appreciated the fact that the lectures were both live and recorded, it made my week a lot more flexible. The sections were very interesting and I think very well adjusted to the online sphere. The assignments too were very flexible and I loved the combination of online and scavenger hunt/outdoor activities.

Professor Brodersen, Aleca, and Joseph did an amazing job of keeping the class engaging even through the online format. There were lots of interactive activities that involved exploring the New Haven environment. We received foldscopes at the beginning of the semester so we were still able to conduct research on stem and leaf cells from home and then talk about it over zoom. Professor Brodersen also has a setup that made his zoom lectures very easy to understand and I never found myself distracted or lost within the powerpoints. I would say that lectures during the covid time are quite hard.  Knowing that watching the recordings later on 2x speed is an option makes it a lot harder to log onto zoom and go to class. This of course has no reflection on the course but on my work ethic this year and the challenges of Zoom fatigue. I can't imagine what the class looks like in a normal year with 200+ students in a big lecture hall.  I greatly enjoyed the intimacy of our course and the more personal learning.
I thought Professor Broderson did a great job with zoom classes. He also was very understanding that there was a pandemic.
N/A
everything was successful

Succeeded: Virtual lecture was well put together with a digital white board and other advanced technology the teacher implemented.
Weaknesses: In person learning would be better for experiments and observations.
I appreciated the recorded lectures and their efforts to have us do work off our computers.
Professor Brodersen did an extraordinary job integrating technology and Zoom features to maximize the experience.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think this course is a great science course for non-science majors at Yale.

I would (and have)! I love the premise of this class and I think its description honestly really describes the class so if you're excited by the description you'll really enjoy this class. Because it covers such a broad range of topics, I think it's only expected that some of the topics didn't interest me as much as others (like going into the biology further or specific applications in furniture) however I left with so much more knowledge than I came in with. I always had a fun fact or two from every lecture! Professor Broderson is engaging and warm and although I found the lectures occasionally boring, his energy and passion for the class are obvious and that makes every lecture more fun.

Yes, absolutely!  (I already have) This course is a fantastic course that explores trees in all aspects. We really get to dive into the biology and science-y side of trees while also placing trees in a global lens and exploring their major impact on the world and on us as people. The activities each week are really fun and Interesting ways to apply our knowledge and learn through doing. One week, we were able to determine the age of a violin using the growth rings of the wood, definitely not something you get to do in any other course. There are scavenger hunts and field trips and guest lecturers and Professor Brodersen is fantastic. He enjoys what he teaches and he teaches it well.
Yes I would if they were interested in trees because it was fun and interactive and very thorough.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in learning more about trees and the greater global environment.
Yes.
Yes I would. I learned a lot about trees and it was fascinating.
This class is a nice science gut as long as you don't hate biology. Professor Brodersen intersperses content with interesting examples and tangents, so it is a pleasant class to take.

Absolutely! This class is a great way to fulfill a science requirement and be able to enjoy it. The workload was very manageable and the things you learn in this class are interesting and exciting because you have witnessed them happen outdoors but might now have known what was going on. The professor is enthusiastic and this class will give you a new appreciation for nature!
Yes I would! Whatever your current knowledge level is, you will gain something from taking this course.
Yes, I believe this course provides knowledge of trees thats impactful for everyday life. EVST major or not I recommend this course.
I would recommend this as a low-workload science credit (but wouldn't consider it easy or anything you can coast through re: exams).
Yes, I was surprised to find myself looking at trees and plants after the course with more information and appreciation.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was a synchronous, virtual discussion section, as well as some hands-on activities.
It was a live virtual lecture that was also recorded. We also had live virtual sections.
The class met twice a week and lectures were recorded which allowed for asynchronous learning. In addition to lectures, we had a weekly discussion section with about half the class.
n/a
Recorded lecture
N/A
and live virtual lecture
optional live virtual lecture with weekly discussion section
live virtual lecture/recorded and live virtual discussion section
Live, virtual lectures were also recorded.
Discussion section and individual assignments outside.
Live lectures that were recorded and synchronous virtual seminar section.
Live as well as recorded/optionally asynchronous lecture.
